body_html:
Hi, I tried the suggestions. But these are errors I get. In the first one, y_list = tf.unstack(y[0]) gives error. I am computing the jacobian of model.total_loss wrt model.trainable_weights. So it gives error: Index out of range using input dim 0; input has only 0 dims for 'strided_slice_4' (op: 'StridedSlice') with input shapes: [], [1], [1], [1] and with computed input tensors: input[3] = <1>. In the second one, model.out.shape is (40,10) where 40 is batch size and 10 is dimension. It gives error in syntax: def jacobian(y, x,(model.output.shape):
…
On Tue, Sep 26, 2017 at 7:33 PM, candidj0 ***@***.***> wrote: @shaifugpt <https://github.com/shaifugpt> take a look to your output function, the functions here work for a y = [y0, y1, ...], your output is surely [[y0,y1, ...]] so you can try : def jacobian(y, x): y_list = tf.unstack(y[0]) jacobian_list = [tf.gradients(y_, x)[0] for y_ in y_list] # list [grad(y0, x), grad(y1, x), ...] return tf.stack(jacobian_list) or def jacobian(y, x, size_y): n = size_y loop_vars = [ tf.constant(0, tf.int32), tf.TensorArray(tf.float32, size=n), ] _, jacobian = tf.while_loop( lambda j, _: j < n, lambda j, result: (j+1, result.write(j, tf.gradients(y[0][j], x))), loop_vars) return jacobian.stack() where size_y is the size of the output of your model. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#675 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AbjabSMFJuQqMcQ3G4sNP1hWB6ljYr34ks5smQRPgaJpZM4G9_8_> .
body_text:
Hi,

I tried the suggestions. But these are errors I get.

In the first one, y_list = tf.unstack(y[0]) gives error. I am computing the
jacobian of model.total_loss wrt model.trainable_weights. So it gives
error: Index out of range using input dim 0; input has only 0 dims for
'strided_slice_4' (op: 'StridedSlice') with input shapes: [], [1], [1], [1]
and with computed input tensors: input[3] = <1>.

In the second one, model.out.shape is (40,10) where 40 is batch size and 10
is dimension. It gives error in syntax: def jacobian(y,
x,(model.output.shape):
…
On Tue, Sep 26, 2017 at 7:33 PM, candidj0 ***@***.***> wrote:
 @shaifugpt <https://github.com/shaifugpt> take a look to your output
 function, the functions here work for a y = [y0, y1, ...], your output is
 surely [[y0,y1, ...]] so you can try :

 def jacobian(y, x):
     y_list = tf.unstack(y[0])
     jacobian_list = [tf.gradients(y_, x)[0] for y_ in y_list]  # list [grad(y0, x), grad(y1, x), ...]
     return tf.stack(jacobian_list)

 or

 def jacobian(y, x, size_y):
     n = size_y
     loop_vars = [
         tf.constant(0, tf.int32),
         tf.TensorArray(tf.float32, size=n),
     ]
     _, jacobian = tf.while_loop(
         lambda j, _: j < n,
         lambda j, result: (j+1, result.write(j, tf.gradients(y[0][j], x))),
         loop_vars)
     return jacobian.stack()

 where size_y is the size of the output of your model.

 —
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#675 (comment)>,
 or mute the thread
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AbjabSMFJuQqMcQ3G4sNP1hWB6ljYr34ks5smQRPgaJpZM4G9_8_>
 .
body:
Hi,

I tried the suggestions. But these are errors I get.

In the first one, y_list = tf.unstack(y[0]) gives error. I am computing the
jacobian of model.total_loss wrt model.trainable_weights. So it gives
error: Index out of range using input dim 0; input has only 0 dims for
'strided_slice_4' (op: 'StridedSlice') with input shapes: [], [1], [1], [1]
and with computed input tensors: input[3] = <1>.

In the second one, model.out.shape is (40,10) where 40 is batch size and 10
is dimension. It gives error in syntax: def jacobian(y,
x,(model.output.shape):

On Tue, Sep 26, 2017 at 7:33 PM, candidj0 <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @shaifugpt <https://github.com/shaifugpt> take a look to your output
> function, the functions here work for a y = [y0, y1, ...], your output is
> surely [[y0,y1, ...]] so you can try :
>
> def jacobian(y, x):
>     y_list = tf.unstack(y[0])
>     jacobian_list = [tf.gradients(y_, x)[0] for y_ in y_list]  # list [grad(y0, x), grad(y1, x), ...]
>     return tf.stack(jacobian_list)
>
> or
>
> def jacobian(y, x, size_y):
>     n = size_y
>     loop_vars = [
>         tf.constant(0, tf.int32),
>         tf.TensorArray(tf.float32, size=n),
>     ]
>     _, jacobian = tf.while_loop(
>         lambda j, _: j < n,
>         lambda j, result: (j+1, result.write(j, tf.gradients(y[0][j], x))),
>         loop_vars)
>     return jacobian.stack()
>
> where size_y is the size of the output of your model.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/675#issuecomment-332206689>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AbjabSMFJuQqMcQ3G4sNP1hWB6ljYr34ks5smQRPgaJpZM4G9_8_>
> .
